title: 106_hr4730
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia Recognition Act". The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia are descendants and political successors to the original Creek Indian Nation at the time of European contact and signatories of the 1832 Treaty of Washington. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, descendants and political successors to the signatories of the 1832 Treaty of Washington, declined removal and continue to operate as a sovereign tribe with over 2,500 eligible members residing close to their ancestral homeland in Georgia. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, with over 2,500 eligible members, chose not to be removed according to the 1832 Treaty of Washington. They operate as a sovereign tribe with a viable tribal government, continuing their political and social existence near their ancestral homeland in Georgia. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, comprising those Lower Creeks who declined removal under the 1832 Treaty of Washington, continues its political and social existence with a viable tribal government. In 1972, the tribe petitioned for Federal recognition as the Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe East of the Mississippi River. In 1972, the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia petitioned the Bureau of Indian Affairs for Federal recognition but lacked critical historical information due to a lack of education and resources. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia lacked competent counsel and technical assistance in their petition for Federal recognition, leading to critical omissions and denial in 1981. Despite this, political leaders of the Tribe have been recognized by the Federal Government, the government of Georgia, and local governments. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "member" refers to an enrolled member of the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia or an individual placed on the membership rolls according to this Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Tribe" refers to the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia. SEC. 4. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. Federal recognition is extended to the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, making them eligible for all federal benefits and services available to recognized Indian tribes and their members. This includes laws and regulations applicable to Indians without the need for a reservation. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia is now federally recognized, allowing them to access all federal benefits and services available to recognized Indian tribes and their members, regardless of reservation status. The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 is applicable to the Tribe and its members. SEC. 5. RESERVATION. The Tribe can transfer land to the Secretary for trust within 2 years, establishing the initial reservation land. Gaming is prohibited on the trust land. SEC. 6. BASE MEMBERSHIP ROLL. The Tribe must submit a membership roll to the Secretary within 120 days of the Act's enactment, based on the Tribe's Constitution. The Secretary will publish the roll in the Federal Register, and the Tribe is responsible for keeping it current. The Tribe has the right to determine future membership. The Tribe must submit a membership roll to the Secretary within 120 days of the Act's enactment, based on the Tribe's Constitution and Bill of Rights. The Secretary will publish the roll in the Federal Register, and the Tribe is responsible for keeping it current. Future membership is determined by the Tribe, with individuals needing to be lineal descendants of those on the base membership roll and maintain political relations with the Tribe. The reservation established by this Act will be considered Indian country under Federal and tribal jurisdiction. This Act will not affect any treaties or rights secured to tribes mentioned in the Act.
